meta.description:
Label Generation Rules for Norwegian

Overview

This document specifies a reference set of Label Generation Rules for Norwegian using a language-specific repertoire appropriate for a second level domain.

Standalone LGR:This Reference LGR is designed to be used as is, or with suitable modifications in a zone that does not cater to IDNs other than those valid under this LGR. While it is anticipated that this LGR may be used in a zone that also supports LDH (ASCII) labels, this LGR lacks features that would allow its use in the context of another LGR in the same zone, and it may contain other features incompatible with such use.

This document is a Review Draft and not final. Any version numbers shown are those of a possible future release. However, the draft may undergo significant revisions before any publication, or may be withdrawn.

Repertoire

Most references converge on 43 (36+7) Latin code points with a few additional extensions.

There is no IDN table published in the IANA Repository of IDN Practices by a .no ccTLD, but the registry provides IDN information [700].

Norwegian is not a single language. Instead, there are two closely related but different written languages (Bokmål and Nynorsk). As both of them are written in the same country and the differences are relatively minor for purposes of IDNs, this LGR covers both, by extending the repertoire slightly.

Excluded code points

Letters documented in some references but not included:

  • U+00E2 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+00EF LATIN SMALL LETTER I WITH DIAERESIS

  • U+00F9 LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH GRAVE

  • U+00FB LATIN SMALL LETTER U WITH CIRCUMFLEX

  • U+01CE LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH CARON

Extended code points

A number of letters not considered essential to writing the core vocabulary of the language are nevertheless in common use. Where they have not been added to the core repertoire, they are flagged as “extended-cp” in the table of code points. A context rule is provided that by default will prohibit labels with such extended code points. To support extended single code points or code point sequences, delete the context “extended-cp” from their repertoire definition.

The following extended code points in particular are needed to write Northern Sami, a minority language in Norway.

  • U+010D LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH CARON

  • U+0111 LATIN SMALL LETTER D WITH STROKE

  • U+0144 LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH ACUTE ACCENT (alternate for N with tilde in Lule Sami)

  • U+014B LATIN SMALL LETTER ENG

  • U+0161 LATIN SMALL LETTER S WITH CARON

  • U+0167 LATIN SMALL LETTER T WITH STROKE

  • U+017E LATIN SMALL LETTER Z WITH CARON

Variants

No variants are applicable when using the LGR in a standalone fashion.

Character Classes

This LGR does not define named character classes.

Rules

Common Rules

  • Hyphen Restrictions — restrictions on the allowable placement of hyphens (no leading/ending hyphen and no hyphen in positions 3 and 4). These restrictions are described in Section 4.2.3.1 of RFC 5891 [120]. They are implemented here as context rule on U+002D (-) HYPHEN-MINUS.

  • Leading Combining Marks — restrictions on the allowable placement of combining marks (no leading combining mark). This rule is described in Section 4.2.3.2 of RFC 5891 [120].

Actions

This LGR includes the default actions for LGRs as well as the action needed to invalidate labels with misplaced combining marks. They are marked with ⍟. For a description see [RFC 7940].

Methodology and Contributors

This reference LGR for the Norwegian language for the second level has been developed by Michel Suignard and Asmus Freytag, verified in expert reviews by Michael Everson, Nicholas Ostler, and Wil Tan, and based on multiple open public consultations.

Changes from Version 1

Language tag has been updated.

Changes from Version 2

Unicode Version has been updated.

References

General references for the language:

  • Norsk språkråd, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

  • Hovdenak, Marit, et al. 1994. Nynorskordboka: definisjons- og rettskrivings- ordbok. Oslo: Det norske samlaget. ISBN 82-521-4121-8- The repertoire covers Bokmål and Nynorsk

  • Wikipedia: “Norwegian orthography”, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norwegian_alphabet

  • Omniglot: “Norwegian (norsk)” https://www.omniglot.com/writing/norwegian.htm

Other reference cited in this document:

[RFC 7940]
Davies, K. and A. Freytag, “Representing Label Generation Rulesets Using XML”, RFC 7940, August 2016, https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc7940

In the listing of the repertoire by code point, references starting from [0] refer to the version of the Unicode Standard in which the corresponding code point was initially encoded. Other references (starting from [100]) document usage of code points. For more details, see the Table of References below.

reference.comment: Code points cited were originally encoded in Unicode Version 1.1

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Standard, Version 11.0.0, ( Mountain View, CA: The Unicode Consortium, 2018. ISBN 978-1-936213-19-1) https://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode11.0.0/
Internetstiftelsen i Sverige (IIS), “IDN Reference table for Norwegian language” https://github.com/dotse/IDN-ref-tables/blob/master/language-tables/norwegian-lang-ref-table.txt
RFC 5891, Internationalized Domain Names in Applications (IDNA): Protocol https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5891

reference.comment: This table lists only the characters outside the set a-z. Some obvious typographical errors have been corrected

references.reference: ISO/IEC 6937 Third Ed. 2001-12-17- Information technology — Coded graphic character set for text communication — Latin alphabet: Table D.1 (p 35) Use of Latin alphabetic characters.

reference.comment: Code points cited form the standard set

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: “Bokmål-Norwegian” https://www.evertype.com/alphabets/bokmaal-norwegian.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from an extended set

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: “Bokmål-Norwegian" https://www.evertype.com/alphabets/bokmaal-norwegian.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are rare or archaic

references.reference: Everson, Michael. The Alphabets of Europe: “Bokmål-Norwegian” https://www.evertype.com/alphabets/bokmaal-norwegian.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the set of Main Letters

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Norwegian Bokmål [nb] https://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/nb.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the Auxiliary set

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Norwegian Bokmål [nb] https://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/nb.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the Auxiliary set for Nynorsk [nn]

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR) Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Norwegian Nynorsk [nn] https://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/nn.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 1: Letters essential for the language

references.reference: Norsk språkråd, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 2: Letters commonly used, but not essential

references.reference: Norsk språkråd, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 3: Letters used for names, in common practice

references.reference: Norsk språkråd, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are of category 4: Letters that are rarely used

references.reference: Norsk språkråd, in Icelandic Council for Standardization. 1992. Nordic cultural requirements on information technology. Reykjavík: Staðlaráð Íslands. ISBN 9979-9004-3-1

reference.comment: Code points cited are supported in a national edition of ISO-646.

references.reference: ISO/IEC 646:1991 — Information technology — ISO 7-bit coded character set for information interchange

reference.comment: According to this reference, the alphabet is listed as using the full basic set A-Z

references.reference: Wikipedia: “Latin Alphabets” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_alphabets - accessed 2015-10-31

reference.comment: The table only lists code points beyond A-Z

references.reference: Wikipedia: “Latin Alphabets” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_alphabets accessed 2015-10-31.

reference.comment: Code points cited are accented letters used particularly, but not exclusively in Nynorsk or foreign words

references.reference: Wikipedia: “Norwegian orthography” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norwegian_orthography-Wikipedia: “Norwegian orthography” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norwegian_orthography

reference.comment: Code points cited are the non-ASCII code points listed by the registry for .no domain

references.reference: UNINETT Norid AS, “Domain name policy for .no" https://www.norid.no/en/regelverk/navnepolitikk/

reference.comment: Code points cited are cited as ocurring in Norwegian spelling dictionaries or commonly used in rendering place names

references.reference: Standard Norge, in Forskning.no, December 2009 “Hvor enkelt er alphabetet" https://www.forskning.no/sprak-standardisering/2009/12/hvor-enkelt-er-alfabetet

reference.comment: Code points cited are extensions needed for writing Sami languages written in Norway

references.reference: Standard Norge, in Forskning.no, December 2009 “Hvor enkelt er alphabetet" https://www.forskning.no/sprak-standardisering/2009/12/hvor-enkelt-er-alfabetet

rule.name: leading-combining-mark
rule.comment: RFC 5891 restrictions on placement of combining marks ⍟

rule.name: hyphen-minus-disallowed
rule.comment: RFC 5891 restrictions on placement of U+002D ⍟
no consecutive hyphens in third and fourth

rule.name: extended-cp
rule.comment: context to gate off code points from the extended range, matches no label ⍟

action.comment: by default, labels with leading combining marks are invalid
